author: vogelito
content: Hi - rookie question. Is there replay protection in Ethereum across hard forks? (please let me know if there's a better place to ask this question).

author: vogelito
content: More specifically, is a legacy (non-EIP1559) transaction signed on my London/Ropsten geth node valid on the pre-london (berlin)/ropsten network?

author: mariusvanderwijden
content: Depends if you signed with an eip-155 signer (one five five) or not

author: mariusvanderwijden
content: Eip155 specified replay protection across forks

author: vogelito
content: Thanks Marius. Is Geth (v1.10.4) an EIP-155 signer? I would assume yes, right?

author: vogelito
content: (using rpc eth_sendTransaction)

author: mariusvanderwijden
content: Yes, we even soft-reject non-eip155 signed transactions via rpc (can be disabled with rpc.allow_unprotected_txs)

author: vogelito
content:
Right. That's very odd. I can swear we signed a transaction via eth_sendTransaction that seems to have made it to our pre-london geth node (on a different block height).

Is there an easy way to tell if a tx was signed with EIP-155? (I would assume so, but not sure).

The transaction is this one:
https://ropsten.etherscan.io/tx/0x4551cee61076ef813876d400ecea64d071f31c665b15f3b5091624c00bc86dc5

content: It's replay protected, the replay protection modifies the 'v' value of the signature. For further questions please use the stackexchange ethereum.stackexchange.com
